Yesterday is a great point and click adventure from the developers who brought you Runaway. Things are not what they seem in this great story of deceit and mystery. You start out as Henry White and his friend cooper who works for a charitable company that helps the homeless.  Well at your first stop you find two crazy guys doing some weird ritual and they end up trying to kill you. You win out and the game flashes forward some time.

Now you take over our main protagonist John Yesterday who has amnesia and is trying to figure out who he really is and about his past. You work for Henry White doing research for him when you start remembering things and realize all is not what it seems. This all leads up to a choice of four different endings and will give you some replay value to see them all.

The art style is fantastic and really fits with the game. Gameplay is what you would get from point and click adventures with some tough challenging puzzles but nothing too hard to accomplish.  There‚Äôs also a hint button you can use to help you out if you‚Äôre stuck which recharges over time after every use. This way you do actually have to try. I did really like when you would click on something the characters wouldn‚Äôt take forever to walk to the item. The characters would appear next the object which is a big plus as sometimes it can seem forever to search areas on other games of this genre.

Pendulo Studios have done another great job at bringing us a great story with romance, humor, and mystery which deserves to be noticed. Only thing I wish is the game was a little longer to enjoy. reviewText:
GAMEPLAY: As a classic Sierra/LucasArts-style adventure game, Yesterday tries very hard to smooth over the inherent tedium of the genre. There is very limited walking animation, as the player most often warps directly to the focal point of a click. There is a built-in hint system that nudges rather than spoilers with a timer that attempts to keep the player from exploiting it (the timer is very short however, so if you're stuck, you'll get your answer soon enough). On the plus side, this keeps the game moving; there is some question, however, whether or not this diminishes the investment one might put into solving the puzzles and the sense of accomplishment that acts as the only game-y reward in this style of game. The puzzles are reasonable. The few leaps of logic are easy to work with given the hint system and the simple fact that madly clicking all over the screen will often yield progress. It is also worth noting that it is entirely impossible to fail at this game. There are no scenarios that actually present a failure state despite the narrative suggesting the imminence of danger to the player character.

STORY/PLOT: Classic adventure games are all about story and puzzles. The overwhelming sense is that Pendulo wanted to make a 20 hour game but only had the time/budget/skill for 4 hours. As a result, there are poorly developed characters with inexplicable motivation, rushed exposition, an abrupt ending, and (perhaps most jarringly) an over-reliance on hackneyed hero tropes (looking at you Buddhist Vodoo sensei). The game's narrative approach is best executed in the very beginning. Without giving too much away, if you find yourself strongly disliking the initial player character, rest assured that it is one of the few well-executed narrative devices the game offers.

STYLE: The graphical style appears to be suggestive of a comic book style with text pop-ups and concurrent frames of action. The character models are generally horrible. The presentation of the characters is also not done any favors from the Fallout 1/2 style dialogue windows where characters look directly at the camera while speaking with very little facial animation or proper lip synching. Given the limitations of the game's production, I am inclined to forgive this forray into the Uncanny Valley, but it does have the effect of rendering what limited characterization and drama that does exist flat and often laughable. It would have been much more effective to merely voice the dialogue in the regular gameplay field. As to the voice acting itself, I am pleased that it is far from the game's greatest failing. It is certainly a far stretch from exemplary, but it convey's its meaning ably enough to not be the biggest distraction in the unfolding of the game's ambitious plot.

BOTTOM LINE: I cannot recommend this game unless you are dying for a semi-3D adventure and have played literally everything else. The plot is disjointed. The characters are shallow. The puzzles are uninspired and require little to no cleverness or ingenuity. Perhaps the 70's grindhouse Satanic cult theme will entice you, but much like the afore mentioned efforts, that too does little to honor the glory of the dark master. Avoid Yesterday like yesterday's sushi.

reviewText:
Yesterday is my favorite of Pendulo's adventure games. It still has a touch of the madcap zaniness that was hit or miss with the Runaway series as well as The Next Big Thing but distilled into a supernatural thriller with enough good twists and turns to keep you entertained until the end.

Most of the gameplay has you playing as John Yesterday, professional investigator for multi-billionaire Henry White. Unfortunately, John has amnesia, but Pendulo went all in making this amnesia story one for the books. As a story, it constantly subverts your expectations, right from the opening dedication where you think it'll be an adventure game about helping the homeless. Gradually, as the layers of the story get peeled away and start to form a cohesive whole, it turns into something special. The characters are memorable aside from John's stock love interest. She has all the personality of Gina from Runaway: A Road Adventure, which is to say she none. Liz Allaire she is not. At least all the dialogue is delivered with much aplomb, or at least up to Pendulo's usual standards.

As for the puzzles, some reviews have touched upon them being easy but I found myself having to use the built in help system a few times after having exhausted all possible solutions, but at least this time most of the solutions make sense in the game world. No 'peanut butter' puzzles to be found. That said, it's possible to acquire 'red herring' items which can add some unneeded difficulty to puzzles. For the most part, areas are limited to two or three screens at a time which keeps frustration at a minimum.

The save system is kind of weird. It doesn't break the mold as badly as The Next Big Thing tried to do but is more like what you find in Machinarium or Botanicula, whereby your progress is saved automatically but you can select scenes to replay as if you were watching a movie on DVD.

Great story, great characters, great presentation. Pendulo's really come into their own after their wacky adventures in Runaway. I'd be down for Yesterday 2 if they've got one in the works.

Yesterday is a very well-crafted dark thriller and mystery story, revolving around satanic cults and one of the best-written amnesia cases in video games. Long version:
Yesterday is probably the strangest game P√©ndulo Studios made since they hit big in 2001. It moves away from the previous titles‚Äô colourful and light atmosphere and introduces us a bloody thriller involving satanic cults, torture, a serial killer, and a big load of mystery in the form of the protagonist, who suffers from a very strange case of amnesia.

Since this is a dark story, the visuals reflect this all the way: the scenes are realistic and use mainly darker tones, but they are not moody. The storytelling is done by using European style comic panels with probably the best voice acting we heard so far in a P√©ndulo game.
The puzzles are quite straightforward. You will probably spend more time with cross-inventory trial and error than trying to figure out what the developers intended for a certain scene.

The greatest problem with the game is the length. It barely reaches four hours if you are even decent at adventure games. I forgot to make a save by quitting (another shortcoming: you cannot save) and I had to race through the story again to watch the other endings; this is how I realised you can speed through the whole game in less than 20 minutes. reviewText: Though it may be short, this dark fantasy point-and-click is a must-buy!  The quasi-cel shaded characters, in true Pendulo tradition, are expertly crafted.  The backgrounds look great, running the gamut from super-detailed (the antique book shop) to impressionistic (the mystical Himalayan temple), depending on the mood.  The in-game animations are brief and subtle, full of rapid cuts, dramatic freeze frames, and often taking place within comic book panels.  Just reading this, you may think that this animation style sounds cheap -- in actuality it makes the game feel like an electric combo of thriller film and fast-paced graphic novel.  The narrative involves dark magic, torture, serial killers and a centuries-old Satanic cult.  While all of these elements have been used countless times before, Yesterday handles them with real style, assembling them into a highly engaging story with some very unique twists (this coming from a guy who has read a lot of fiction about this type of thing).  The puzzles may be simpler than in some of the past Pendulo games, but they aren't exactly easy unless you turn lousy cheater and invoke the hint feature.  DON'T INVOKE THE HINT FEATURE!  The game will last longer and be far more satisfying if you don't!\n\nFor my money, this game is definitely worth the full price.  If you are still on the fence about it, it's constantly on sale for 4 bucks or less, and that is a true steal for what you are getting.

reviewText:
What can I say about Yesterday?

Yesterday is a rather good mystery adventure game for those moments you cannot be bothered to do a lot of heavy thinking. The puzzles are very logical, but still require you to put some effort into things. Every level is a gem and you'll feel happy when you finish it. None of the puzzles require you to take any notes or use items in ways you'd never imagine them being used. This game is really more geared for when you just want to play a short game and not bother with too much hassle, it's a casual game.

The story offers you a nice little mystery of which I won't tell you anything in order not to spoil anything. It won't leave you reeling with any great revelations, but you are offered some interesting characters and situations and sometimes things do turn out just that little bit different from what you were expecting.
The themes can a bit heavy even though nothing too gruesome is shown, but I would recommend that players at least be teens before trying out this little gem.

The voice acting in this game was sublime, the voice actors really did a good job.
What I did not like about the game was the lack of graphical options. The game was pretty and ran very good, but like most PC gamers I'd at least like the option to view the game optimally from my machine, which differs from other machines. Especially in a game that offers a lot of story and thus quite a few cutscenes. Still, some of the setpieces were fantastic.

The only other complaint I can offer was that this was not a very long game. With only something of three to four hours and a replayability of nill (it is an adventure game, after all), this is rather limited. But the story was finished and the last thing this game needed was unnecessary padding.
If you are looking for a good value:time ratio I'd say that anything lower than $/¬£/‚Ç¨5.00 is a steal, 7.50 seems fair, 10 is the very upper limit. But this is something everyone has to decide for themselves, of course.

Anyway, this game comes highly recommended, enjoy!

The story offers you a nice little mystery of which I won't tell you anything in order not to spoil anything. It won't leave you reeling with any great revelations, but you are offered some interesting characters and situations and sometimes things do turn out just that little bit different from what you were expecting.
The themes can a bit heavy even though nothing too gruesome is shown, but I would recommend that players at least be teens before trying out this little gem.

The voice acting in this game was sublime, the voice actors really did a good job.
What I did not like about the game was the lack of graphical options. The game was pretty and ran very good, but like most PC gamers I'd at least like the option to view the game optimally from my machine, which differs from other machines. Especially in a game that offers a lot of story and thus quite a few cutscenes. Still, some of the setpieces were fantastic.

The only other complaint I can offer was that this was not a very long game. With only something of three to four hours and a replayability of nill (it is an adventure game, after all), this is rather limited. But the story was finished and the last thing this game needed was unnecessary padding.
If you are looking for a good value:time ratio I'd say that anything lower than $/¬£/‚Ç¨5.00 is a steal, 7.50 seems fair, 10 is the very upper limit. But this is something everyone has to decide for themselves, of course.

Anyway, this game comes highly recommended, enjoy!

reviewText:
I'm really torn between recommending and not recommending this game.

The game itself is short, it also flatters itself by having a hint system, which you most likely won't need at all, because it's too easy. The story is all over the place, I had a hard time following it, or taking interest in it. Characters are easily forgettable, the game takes turns in dumping you the plot, then has nothing happening for the next hour. The graphics are really weird, the atmosphere is beautiful, like in most Pendulo games, but the character sprites feel out of place, like you are playing the Runaway characters in a Chzo's Mythos game. Not taking anything away from the overall presentation, which is nice, but little tidbits like that sometimes break immersion in the worst places. The mechanics in the game are brilliant - your character doesn't waddle around the screen, instead it fades out of its position and quickly fades in near the spot you have clicked, which speeds up the gameplay. The game is EASY, puzzles are intuitive, some repeat themselves one too many times, you might find the occasional cheap hard to find puzzles here and there, especially towards the end, which still make no sense, but overall the game doesn't really challenge your adventure gaming skills.

I feel like Pendulo tried to make a short and fresh new game with a compelling story worth your time and witty puzzles, and they have kinda did some stuff right, but ultimately - the desired result wasn't achieved. A solid 5-6/10 in my opinion.

Put it like this - if you are a hardcore point-and-click adventure game fan and if you find the game in a sale or in a bundle - buy it, you won't regret it. It's not worth the 10 bucks it asks for currently, but if you can get it for cheaper, try it out.

Half of the appeal is  figuring out the puzzles by yourself, but when you get stumped cause you tried every waking thing, only to find out the solution is something beyond reasonable thought then you just encounter puzzle game padding for the sake of padding. Half of the negativity is coming from failed expectations, but that's mainly on me. If you like games like monkey island, give this a try, but ONLY once it goes on sale. Sorry Pendulo. Maybe next time.

Yesterday is a mystery/horror point and click adventure game.  It's different from others in its genre:  it's very dark  and has some unexpected plot twists.  I was struck by the higher quality of writing in this game than in previous projects by its studio like the Runaway series.  There's less corny dialogue and characters awkwardly talking out loud to themselves.  It's not quite as tight as their later venture, The Next Big Thing, which I'd recommend over this one, but if you like games in this genre aimed at adults (this is NOT a point & click game for kids in the slightest--way too dark with satanic cults involved), you will very likely enjoy this one.  It has four different endings, one of which is meant to be funny and involves some Easter Eggs if you played other games by Pendulo.

The good:
The plot is well done and moves at a good pace.  It will not always make sense your first hour into it, but that is intentional.  It works well like an average mystery-horor novel.  It won't blow you out of the water, but it's better than most.  The inventory system is easy to use, and I think the best of Pendulo's work.  The voice acting works: the characters seem to talk when it's logical and there's little inner monologue .  The hint system is well designed.

The neutral:
While not often, a few puzzles feel like make-work, but they aren't too bad.  As some of the character's inner natures aren't revealed until the end, you may not grow attached to them.  People are sharply divided over the quality of some of the endings, but it bothered me less than most, I think.  The game clocked in at 5.4 hours for me on my first playthrough, mostly in two sittings.

The Poor:
You sometimes get this feeling like this game could be a bit more than it is.  It works where it needs to work, but it's not genre-defining or a favorite game.  I got it cheap on a bundle Pendulo sale, and it was worth that price, probably the 2nd best Pendulo game of the four in the bundle that I have played. Some characters are poorly developed leaving a few loose ends to the story that seem odd but don't warrant a sequel (the master, Boris, etc.).  Two sets of characters just seem so stereoptypical to be off-putting: the American tourists and the French concierge.

Overall:
It's a solid game that if you like this genre you will probably mostly enjoy.  You probably won't brag about it with friends, or hope for a sequel. You'll enjoy solving some puzzles and seeing where it goes.  It is what it mostly presents itself to be and nothing more.  Get it on sale. It's not for kids and it's really dark--just be ready for that if that bothers you.

reviewText:
This is a great adventure point and click game developed by a European studio which really shows. They've made some other great games of the same style such as The next Big Thing. This studio is a true gem because it took everything the oldschool Telltale games had and modernized it. Here you'll see challenging puzzles, a great story and so much more. Honestly it will remind of Sam and Max, Grimfandango and the Broken Sword series. The story could be categorized as a horror, but with a humorous twist. The setting tends to be eerie but the dialog and the funny characters give the game a charm unlike any other.

Bear in mind the options menu is non existent, the graphics/textures could be a lot better, there isn't a functional menu to the game and while voice acting is very good in my personal opinion some voice actors make some characters very stale and boring which could be better.

Googling isn't really neccessary anymore because there's a hint mechanic in the game that will help you if you get stuck although you won't be able to bash it constantly.

If you like oldschool point and clicks where sometimes you'll bash your head against a table because you won't be able to figure out how to get to the next scene, and when you finally make it won't believe how stupid you were this is the game for you.

A must buy for all you point and click enthusiasts especially now when it's dirt cheap on sale.

reviewText:
In theory, I should like this game... I like adventure games, I like puzzles, and I like supernatural stories.  However, this game seemed to fall flat on every front, and is exceptionally short as well.  Once the story plot gets revealed more, it felt like that should be just the prologue - they could have done so much more with it.  The hermit/monk sequence and overarching plot left me yearning to play through some more flashback scenarios around when the character[s] developed originally to unlock other game mechanics that change things up as you learned about them... but they left that mostly unexplored.

On the puzzle front, there were a couple parts in which it felt like I was accomplishing something, but by and large the puzzles weren't that puzzling or satisfying.  The worst kind of puzzles are the obvious ones or the ones that just leave you trying different things ... and Yesterday primarily had those two kinds.  Consequentially, there either wasn't too much of an 'aha' moment, or that special moment when you eventually figure things out may be marred with a 'no way' moment that makes you question whether that is really practical and saps the fun out of it.

If the game goes on sale for a few bucks, I think it might still be worth it for adventure game fans... but in general I can't recommend it unless you are really looking for something quick and different to change things up for a few hours (it took me about 4-ish hours).  On the plus side, the art is quite well done and charming, but something a little grittier and less cartoony might have been more well-suited to its darker theme.  It's very similar to the Runaway games and The Next Big Thing on the art direction front... but one size doesn't always fit all.
